text: goodnight tomorrow any year my needle
drops Anthony Fantana here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and this
is my album review of the night's
planning to rocks and mount Sims
tomorrow in a year on this LP the
Swedish electro pop duo the knife take
on some collaborators I've already
mentioned planning to rock already
mentioned mountains but to throw more
names on top of the pile this thing was
commissioned as a soundtrack slash opera
for the Danish performance art group
Hotel pro-forma and the subject matter
Charles Darwin his work and the big t
theory of evolution which isn't that
unusual considering that this very same
performance art group also put on a
production about Leon theremin the
inventor of the most untouchable musical
instrument the theremin so that's the
concept which is pretty unusual pretty
experimental so that must mean this
thing is really great so I'm going to
give it a ten out of ten because it's a
perfect album because it's experimental
good so in all honesty this thing is a
complete and utter mess printed to two
discs and it just throws abstract after
abstract at you without actually pulling
any of them together which you would
think would happen considering that this
thing is so heavily based upon a concept
and I feel like everyone's enamored with
the concept more than they are the
actual music itself I can just imagine
people in my head listening to this
hearing the noise and the dissonant
tones and just thinking things evolving
man in order to look at this LP as music
as a musical piece we have to separate
it from its concept because it's concept
has little to nothing to do with the
sound and the texture of this LP the
whole thing starts with these really
glitchy electronic blips that build into
this multi-layered drone and this is
where the operatic vocals first show up
now it feels like it's building towards
something and this really had me excited
about the LP I thought I was really
going to be in for something
very conceptual very avant-garde very
perceptive all this noise all this
feedback and distortion starts feeding
itself into the mix and then once it
gets into the third track the whole LP
just gets increasingly more and more
difficult without rhyme or reason the
chords and the melodies get more
dissonant and the sounds get harsher and
then these field recordings start
introducing themselves but it never
really clicks to me as aa genius all I
can say is it doesn't really stimulate
me like a John Cage prepared piano piece
and it doesn't really make me squirm
like a Murs bound no escape it doesn't
put a chill up my spine like any given
track off of Laurie Anderson's big
science and it doesn't horrify me like
many of the dark ambient pieces on any
lust more an album a lot of the
keyboards and the noises just callously
repeat themselves over and over and I
can hear now people are like so because
this thing is about evolution we're just
going to give it the green light to be
boring Karen Anderson as Fever Ray put
together a pretty dark LP last year and
I know her brother makes a pretty
experimental strange stuff by himself
but still I think their solo stuff is
kind of a huge jump from what this LP is
trying to do and the knife widely
acknowledges that they have no prior
experience scoring or even frequenting
operas and I think this album is an
example of the train wreck that can
happen when you approach avant-garde
composition like a blind date
now the second LP is very musical and I
guess you could say it's where this
thing really pays off it opens up with
an ease box which is very beautiful very
tonal very somber and it even opens up
later into the track coloring of pigeons
which I gave a nine out of ten to on
track reviews a score I still stand by
and a fantastic piece of this LP now
even though coloring of pigeons is a
really awesome track after that song the
entire LP proceeds to go batshit insane
and turn itself into a joke throwing
these four to the floor beats into the
song seeds with
sounds like it's made up of all these
fruity loops preset loops and sounds and
sort of to add insult to injury they
throw a track at the end of the album
called the height of summer which sounds
dangerously close to heart beats yes the
song heartbeats that we all know and
love it's like an effigy of the track
and it big for you to anyone who is
expecting this LP to be anything
interesting fun accessible or cohesive
now to be honest the knife was
commissioned to do this piece by Hotel
pro-forma so we can only speculate how
much artistic freedom they had over this
LP because they could just be making
music to sort of fit to the very
avant-garde experimental nature of this
performance group plus this thing is a
performance piece there's some footage
on YouTube look for a link and when you
sit down and watch the whole thing there
could be so much more context given to
this soundtrack I just can't help but
feel like for the entire duration of
this album there really should be some
visual to go with this audio I know a
decent amount of people are going to and
already have followed the knife in this
direction just because they're the knife
and all music aside this is a cool
concept and it is kind of an unusual
direction for them to take their music
in but I unfortunately can't follow them
in this direction I'm just not into this
LP and can't help but feel like they
sound like lightweights when you compare
them to the heavyweights of avant-garde
and experimental composition but that's
how I felt about it if you listen to the
LP what did you like about it what did
you hate about it do you like this
direction do you miss the old direction
are they going to go back to that do you
think mmm the knife in collaboration
with mount Sims and planning to rock
tomorrow in a year
Anthony Fantana forever
